_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures, and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for the LanzaJet at Soperton, Georgia.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:
LanzaJet is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. LanzaJet is considered a non-responding facility for releases of the RMP-listed chemicals, so the site utilizes an Emergency Action Plan (EAP).

The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:
The LanzaJet ATJ plant located at 535 Commerce Dr, Soperton, GA,  is designed to convert Ethanol to Synthetic Paraffinic Kerosene (SPK) and Synthetic Paraffinic Diesel (SPD) via the production of ethylene as an intermediate. This process entails three basic conversion steps, followed by a final fractionation step to yield the desired jet or diesel product cut.
?	Ethanol dehydration to ethylene
?	Oligomerization of ethylene and light olefins
?	Hydrogenation of olefins to paraffins and final fractionation

The LanzaJet Alcohol-to-Jet process contains flammable mixtures (that include RMP-regulated substances) in quantities exceeding the RMP threshold. A requirement of the RMP rule is for the affected facility to prepare a worst-case release scenario analysis for each covered process. The LanzaJet is eligible for the RMP Program Level 1 because the facility has not had a reportable release in the previous five years, the distance to the flammable endpoint for a worst-case release is

less than the distance to any public receptor, and the facility has coordinated response efforts with the local emergency planning and response agencies. Under Program Level 1, LanzaJet is only required to include data for the worst-case release scenario, and therefore, only a worst-case scenario is included with this submittal.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:
LanzaJet is not required to implement the Program Level 3 prevention program requirements under the RMP regulations because they are eligible for RMP Program Level 1.
However, LanzaJet is required to comply with the requirements for preventing or minimizing the consequences of catastrophic releases of flammable or explosive chemicals codified under the Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations (29 CFR 1910.119). The required elements of the PSM program relevant to general accidental release prevention are listed below:
?	Employee Participation
?	Process Safety Information
?	Process Hazard Analysis
?	Operating Procedures
?	Contractors
?	Pre-startup Safety Review
?	Mechanical Integrity
?	Hot Work Permit
?	Management of Change
?	Incident Investigation
?	Emergency Planning and Response
?	Compliance Audits
?	Trade Secrets

LanzaJet has a program in place to comply with these items and their specific requirements.

The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:
LanzaJet Soperton facility has had no accidents meeting the definition in 40 CFR 68.42 in the past five years.

The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:
As a non-responding site, LanzaJet has developed a written emergency action plan (EAP) that includes activation of the local emergency notification system and calling 911 from a safe location, and directing an evacuation, including exit route assignments. All employees are trained to assist other employees in a safe and orderly evacuation. Should the scope of any incident exceed the capability of staff, such as a la

rge flammable gas release, fire, or explosion at the facility, the employee discovering the emergency shall follow the protocol provided in the EAP to notify facility personnel, isolate the covered process if safe to do so, evacuate the facility and perform headcount at the designated muster point, and contact emergency responders. Emergency exit routes are through any available gate for this outdoor location and muster points. The facility is a non-responding facility and relies on the Soperton Fire Department when necessary to respond to RMP chemical releases.

Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:
LanzaJet is continually improving and implementing its PSM/RMP program and safety systems. There is a process in place for the management team to review all potential process changes, including recommendations following process hazard analysis and compliance audits.  

LanzaJet has completed this report to provide the public with information about our activities at this facility. We believe that, due to the many controls instituted to maintain a safe operation and our commitment to continuous improvement, an incident affecting our employees, or the surrounding area is unlikely to occur.
